{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3494590,"name":"Team 10034 Programmer","username":"Y.Sean","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/y.sean/{size}/252033_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-28T11:00:21.656Z","cooked":"

Hi everyone,

Context: Our team uses a turret to shoot L4 coral (video), and we are trying to figure out how to aim effectively. This requires the robot’s bumper to be completely aligned parallel with the reef (if possible). Once aligned, we can use location data to adjust our turret and shoot.

As a rookie team, we are not very experienced with advanced tools like PathPlanner or AdvantageScope yet, so those won’t be our first choice for localizing the robot.

We currently have two plans:

Plan A: Limelight

Using a Limelight to detect AprilTags and determine the robot’s position.

Pros:

  • Can provide precise localization by detecting AprilTags on the field.

Cons:

  • We’re not very skilled with using Limelight yet.
  • We’re unsure if it can accurately calculate the robot’s position and provide alignment data.

Plan B: Infrared Sensors

Using 2 or more infrared sensors on the edges of the robot to measure the distance and angle relative to the reef.

Pros:

  • Easier to process and analyze data without relying on complex software.
  • Doesn’t require the robot to be perfectly aligned with the reef to calculate the turret’s aiming angle.

Cons:

  • Infrared sensors may be less accurate compared to Limelight (can anyone confirm this?).
  • Sensors might fail or break, so we’d need to add spares as a precaution.

Question:
What has your experience been with these technologies? Are there specific factors or challenges we should consider when choosing between these two approaches? Also, do you think Limelight or infrared sensors would be better suited for aligning the robot and aiming the turret?

Thank you in advance for your feedback!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-01-28T11:00:29.611Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":49,"reads":231,"readers_count":230,"score":316.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":483951,"topic_slug":"infrared-sensors-vs-limelight-for-robot-localization","display_username":"Team 10034 Programmer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.instagram.com/reel/DFUhSaozsgS/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"FRC 10034｜GammaLand宜蘭聯隊 on Instagram","clicks":116}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":69619,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 10034 Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/infrared-sensors-vs-limelight-for-robot-localization/483951/1","custom_user_title":"Team 10034 Programmer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3494592,"name":"Brad","username":"Bmongar","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bmongar/{size}/228654_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-28T11:08:42.621Z","cooked":"

Localization can be a great benefit but if you aren’t yet prepared to make good use of that then I think the IR sensors are your best bet.

Even if you do use the limelight for localization (which can provide some great benefits) it is probably best to confirm final alignment with the sensors

We’re planning to primarily align using two cameras, but I did do some experiments with the IC laser range finders and think they could work.

Here’s a video of the quick test, which should give a brief idea of the repeatability and function on a pretty idealized test (dining room table against reef branch joint halves).

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-01-28T13:44:01.667Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":138,"readers_count":137,"score":27.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":483951,"topic_slug":"infrared-sensors-vs-limelight-for-robot-localization","display_username":"Sam","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7309,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/infrared-sensors-vs-limelight-for-robot-localization/483951/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3494643,"name":"Jim Sokoloff","username":"sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-28T13:52:10.359Z","cooked":"

Context: This is our first year incorporating vision.

Localization via AprilTags (we’re using Photonvision) is way, way better than I expected in our early testing and I would highly encourage you to do a one week “spike” to see how well vision would work for your use case.

I started down the Laser rangefinding path because I didn’t trust vision would be precise enough. Based on our early testing, I think it would be, especially if you’re able to use multiple cams. Adding sensor fusion with odometry should make it even better.

PS: I’m excited to see the concept of L4 shooting work.

Y.Sean:

Our team uses a turret to shoot L4 coral (video )

That’s incredible! Well done.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-01-28T14:57:30.289Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":106,"readers_count":105,"score":21.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":483951,"topic_slug":"infrared-sensors-vs-limelight-for-robot-localization","display_username":"John Hascall (he)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46267,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Opinions expressed are mine only"},"post_url":"/t/infrared-sensors-vs-limelight-for-robot-localization/483951/8","custom_user_title":"Opinions expressed are mine only","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3494685,"name":"Pedro Braga","username":"predobrega","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/predobrega/{size}/211207_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-28T15:02:24.640Z","cooked":"

Another thing you might want to consider is that the Limelight, when properly configured, will be able to give you a distance reference from the center of the reef face. The ir sensors will only be able to directly give you angle measurements.

Also, by “infrared sensor”, do you mean lidar or standard ir brightness sensors? If it’s the second one, I would strongly advise against it, since they are highly susceptible to external ir sources, and usually don’t provide too accurate of a measurement.

Also, good job on your L4 shooter! Very impressive!

We installed 2 motors with wheels on the turret, and adjust the trajectory by motor speeds. It is still in experiment stage now, I hope it works in official play.
